title: Quiz 1: Civil Litigation Fundamentals
description: Test your knowledge on Causes of Action, Limitation of Actions, Jurisdiction, and Capacity to Sue.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a 'Cause of Action'?

options.text: The written statement filed by the defendant in response to a claim
The entire set of facts that gives rise to an enforceable claim
The monetary value of the subject matter in dispute
The specific court division where a suit is instituted

questions.explanation: A cause of action consists of the facts sufficient to support a valid lawsuit and the legal theory upon which the lawsuit is based.
questions.hint: It involves both the facts and the legal theory.

questions.question: According to the Limitation of Actions Act (Cap. 22), an action founded on contract must be brought within ___BLANK___ years, while an action founded on tort must be brought within ___BLANK___ years.
questions.explanation: Section 4 of the Limitation of Actions Act sets the limit for contract at 6 years and tort at 3 years.
questions.hint: Contract allows for a longer period than Tort.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the 'Next Friend' and 'Guardian ad Litem' are CORRECT? (Select all that apply)

options.text: A minor sues by their Guardian ad Litem
A minor defends by their Guardian ad Litem
A minor sues by their Next Friend
The Next Friend guarantees costs if the plaintiff's claim fails

questions.explanation: Minors sue via a 'Next Friend' (who guarantees costs) and defend via a 'Guardian ad Litem'.
questions.hint: Think about who initiates the action versus who defends it.

questions.question: Match the limitation period to the specific type of action:

richContent.content: Refer to the Limitation of Actions Act guidelines.

questions.explanation: Land is 12 years (Sec 7); Defamation is 1 year; Tort against Govt is 1 year; Employment is generally 3 years (Sec 90).
questions.hint: Defamation and actions against the government have the shortest periods.

questions.question: Analyze the table below regarding Jurisdiction. Which Court Division is INCORRECTLY paired with its subject matter?

richContent.content:
DivisionSubject Matter
AEmployment & Labour Relations CourtTrade Union disputes
BEnvironment and Land CourtTitle to land
CFamily DivisionProbate and Administration
DCommercial & Tax DivisionJudicial Review of Administrative Action

options.text: Pair A
Pair B
Pair C
Pair D

questions.explanation: Judicial Review of Administrative Action belongs to the Judicial Review Division, not the Commercial & Tax Division.
questions.hint: Review the specific mandate of the Commercial & Tax Division versus the Judicial Review Division.

questions.question: A Demand Letter is mandatory in all civil suits guided by the Civil Procedure Rules, 2010, and failure to include it may affect the award of costs.
questions.explanation: Under Order 3, rule 2(d), a demand is required to be made as a matter of law, and excluding it may prevent a party from claiming costs.
questions.hint: Consider the cost implications of rushing to court without warning.

questions.question: What is the Latin term for the equitable principle that prevents lawsuits from being filed when, in fairness to the defendant, too much time has elapsed (even if the statute of limitations hasn't expired)?
questions.explanation: Laches is the equitable doctrine regarding delay. 'Equity aids the vigilant, not the indolent.'
questions.hint: It starts with 'L' and relates to delay in equitable relief.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for calculating the Statute of Limitations correctly:

items.text: Identify the date the cause of action accrued (e.g., date of accident)
Exclude the first day (the day of the event)
Start counting from the next day
Include the last day of the period

questions.explanation: In calculating time, you do not count the first day, but you do count the last day.
questions.hint: Does the clock start ticking the exact second an accident happens, or the next day?

questions.question: Under the 'Without Prejudice' rule, which of the following is protected?

options.text: All correspondence between advocates
Communications genuinely attempting to resolve a dispute
Threats made during negotiations
Final settlement agreements signed by both parties

questions.explanation: The doctrine protects admissions or concessions made during genuine attempts to settle a dispute.
questions.hint: It protects the negotiation process, not the final agreement.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes 'Pecuniary Jurisdiction'?

options.text: The geographical area a court covers
The maximum monetary value of cases a court can entertain
The power of the court to hear criminal matters
The ability of the court to hear appeals

questions.explanation: Pecuniary jurisdiction refers to the monetary limits of a court's authority.
